Graphical abstract By combining DFT and machine learning, Ru1Cu SAA catalyst were designed, showing outstanding activity, selectivity, and resistance to over-dehydrogenation and CC cleavage in alkane dehydrogenation, outperforming Pt. The recent surge in shale gas production has renewed interest in efficient alkane dehydrogenation for the synthesis of fuels and high-value chemicals. However, developing cost-effective catalysts that exhibit high catalytic activity while minimizing over-dehydrogenation and carbon deposition remains a significant challenge. Here, we integrate density functional theory (DFT) calculations with machine learning (ML) to design single-atom alloy (SAA) catalysts for efficient alkane dehydrogenation. Using DFT, we calculate 92 CH bond disassociation energy barriers to construct a dataset, which is used to train eight ML algorithms with 12 features. The top-performing Bagging Regression (BAR) model is then employed to predict CH bond activation energy barriers on the surfaces of 53 SAA candidates, enabling rapid screening of methane dehydrogenation activity. Among these, the Ru1Cu SAA catalyst exhibits outstanding activity, outperforming pure Pt. Detailed DFT calculations confirm that Ru1Cu(111) not only exhibits superior performance in methane dehydrogenation, but also exceptional activity in the dehydrogenation of propane, ethane, and isobutane. Moreover, microkinetic simulations further confirm the high selectivity of the Ru1Cu(111) surface toward propylene during propane dehydrogenation. Feature engineering analyses reveal the critical roles of dehydrogenation steps and the surface energy of the single-atom metal in influencing CH bond activation. These findings underscore the effectiveness of the DFT–ML framework for catalyst discovery and highlight Ru1Cu SAA as a highly active, selective, and stable catalyst with strong resistance to over-dehydrogenation and carbon deposition, making it a highly promising candidate for alkane dehydrogenation. Keywords Alkane dehydrogenation Single atom alloy Structure–activity relationship Density functional theory Machine learning Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Alkanes, the primary constituents of natural gas and crude oil, have emerged as a pivotal player in the energy and chemical industries [1–4]. The recent surge in gas production from shale formations presents a significant opportunity for catalytic innovations to efficiently convert hydrocarbon molecules, such as methane, ethane, propane, and butanes, into value-added chemicals and fuels. These transformations can be achieved by selective activation of paraffinic CH bonds, making the direct catalytic conversion of alkanes into high-value chemicals and liquid fuels a promising pathway for sustainable development [5–10]. Currently, non-oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes stands out due to its superior carbon efficiency and substantially lower CO2 emissions, rendering it particularly attractive for industrial applications [11–13]. However, the activation of CH bonds in alkanes remains a significant hurdle due to their inherent strength, resulting in high energy barriers that hinder efficient bond cleavage [14–16]. In particular, methane, characterized by its high CH bond energy of 439.3 kJ/mol, negligible electron affinity, and zero dipole moment, poses a significant challenge for activation [17–20]. Extensive research has consistently highlighted the exceptional catalytic activities of noble metals, such as Ru, Pt, and Rh [21–23], as well as non-noble metals such as Ni and Co [24,25]. Despite their remarkable activities, these catalysts are often plagued by deactivation due to the accumulation of carbon deposition on their surfaces. To address this issue, significant efforts have been directed towards mitigating their carbon deposition and enhancing their catalyst stability [26–29]. Among the various catalysts explored, single-atom alloys (SAAs) have shown great promise, as they feature a minute fraction of active metal atoms finely dispersed on the surface of an inert-metal host. In 2018, Sykes et al. demonstrated the effectiveness of Pt1Cu SAA in activating CH bonds while mitigating carbon deposition [30]. Subsequently, they also demonstrated the impressive catalytic performance of Rh1Cu SAA in propane dehydrogenation reactions [13]. While these studies highlight the potential of SAAs in CH bond activation, a comprehensive framework for the rational design of catalysts for alkane non-oxidative dehydrogenation is still lacking. Therefore, it is both a scientific imperative and a practical necessity to address this knowledge gap and to establish a systematic understanding of the structure–activity relationships governing SAA catalysts in non-oxidative alkane dehydrogenation. Such development will undoubtedly accelerate the development of SAA catalysts, reducing reliance on resource-intensive trial-and-error approaches. Recently, the integration of machine learning (ML) in material screening and catalyst design has yielded remarkable and promising results. For instance, studies using ML techniques [31,32] have demonstrated high accuracy (with error less than 0.07 eV) in predicting the energy barrier for hydrogenation of C2Hn on SAA surfaces. However, despite its effectiveness, ML often operates as a “black box”, making it challenging to interpret using physical or chemical frameworks. Therefore, to establish ML as a rational design tool, it requires not only effectiveness, but also interpretability. Towards this end, feature engineering emerges as a powerful approach, helping to identify meaningful relationships between features and properties. In this work, a combined DFT/ML approach is utilized to identify high-performance SAA catalysts for the non-oxidative dehydrogenation of alkanes. Feature engineering is used to elucidate the underlying relationships between catalytic performance and atomic structure. We first compute a dataset of 92 CH bond breaking energy barriers using DFT, which is then used to construct 8 different ML models based on readily accessible feature parameters. Our ML training and testing reveal that the Bagging Regression (BAR) algorithm with 12 selected features achieves exceptional predictive accuracy. By applying this model to predict 212 CH bond energy barriers across 53 SAAs (M1Mhost, M1 = Ni, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ir, and Pt, Mhost = Al, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ag, Cd, and Au), we identify Ru1Cu(111) SAA as a top-performing catalyst of dehydrogenation. Feature engineering analyses further reveal insights into the physical and chemical contributions of atomic properties to CH bond activation. Finally, detailed DFT calculations confirm the exceptional performance of Ru1Cu(111) in various alkane dehydrogenation reactions, demonstrating its outstanding activity, selectivity, and resistance to over-hydrogenation and C–C bond cleavage. 2 Methodology section 2.1 DFT calculations All calculations were conducted using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.4.1) [33,34]. The exchange–correlation interactions were modeled utilizing the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the framework of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [35], while the description of core electrons was accomplished through the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [36,37]. Additionally, Grimme's DFT-D3 method was incorporated to assess the influence of van der Waals interactions [38]. The transition state was explored using the dimer [39] and climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) methods [40], followed by verification through vibration frequency calculations. Only one imaginary frequency was identified, confirming the authenticity and uniqueness of the transition state [41]. A plane-wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 500 eV was employed, and energy and force convergence criteria for self-consistent iterations were set at 10−5 eV and 0.02 eV/Å, respectively. For structural optimization, a Monkhorst–Pack k-point grid of 3 × 3 × 1 was sampled within the Brillouin zone. For more details regarding DFT calculations, please refer to the Supplementary Information section. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were performed in the canonical (NVT) ensemble at 773 K to mimic relevant reaction conditions. Temperature control was maintained using a Nosé–Hoover thermostat [42]. A time step of 1 fs was employed, and the total simulation time was 6 ps, which is sufficient to capture the dynamic behavior and structural evolution of the surface atoms. 2.2 ML models All ML algorithms were implemented using the open-source code Scikit-learn [43] in Python3 environment. In this work, eight different supervised ML algorithms were selected, namely Poly Linear Regression (PolyLR), Bayesian Ridge Regression (BRR), Random Forest Regression (RFR), AdaBoosting Regression (ABR), Sure Independence Screening and Sparsifying Operator (SISSO), KNeighbors Regression (KNR), Gradient Boosting Regression (GBR), and Bagging Regression (BAR). Normalization preprocessing was employed for all data in the training and prediction, and the sample data were processed using quadratic terms. To reduce the risk of overfitting and eliminate random effects, the test dataset was reproduced by adding uniformly distributed random noises on the scale of −0.01 to 0.01 of the test set. Additional ML model details are provided in the Supplementary Information. 2.3 Microkinetic simulations Microkinetic simulations were performed by the CATKINAS software package [44–46]. The reaction mechanism consists of nine elementary steps, describing the stepwise dehydrogenation of propane on the metal active site. The simulations were carried out over a temperature range of 323–1023 K under a total pressure of 1 atm, with a total molar feed flow rate of 1 × 10−3 mol/s. Thermodynamic properties were calculated using the NASA polynomial model. The barrier-corrected model of the adsorption/desorption reactions was adopted using collision theory. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Data preparation The energy barrier for CH bond activation is a crucial performance indicator of alkane dehydrogenation catalysts; therefore, we selected the CH bond cleavage energy barrier as our target property. Following this selection, we calculated 92 CH bond breaking energy barriers on the surfaces of 23 SAAs using DFT. Potential energy profiles and schematic diagrams illustrating the adsorption configurations of methane and its corresponding intermediates on the surfaces of SAAs are presented in Figs. 1 and S1, respectively. On the surfaces of most Ni-based SAAs, the dehydrogenation energy barrier for *CH4 was marginally higher than that for *CH3 and *CH2. This observation suggests that once one hydrogen atom is removed from methane, subsequent removal of the other two hydrogen atoms can occur with relative ease. Note that *CH exhibited the highest dehydrogenation energy barrier, surpassing the threshold of 1.20 eV. This finding underscores the potential benefit of inhibiting the formation of carbon deposits on the SAA surface. In the case of Co-based, Cu-based and Au-based SAAs, with the exception of Ni1Cu and Pd1Cu, the dehydrogenation energy barrier for *CH3 on the other SAA surfaces was marginally higher than that for *CH4. This observation strongly suggests that the surfaces of these SAAs are primarily conducive to partial dehydrogenation of alkanes. Similarly, *CH displayed the highest dehydrogenation energy barrier, indicating that the surfaces of this SAA type demonstrated robust resistance to carbon deposition. In the above comparison of all the SAA catalysts, it is evident that Ru1Mhost exhibits the lowest dehydrogenation energy barrier. The dehydrogenation energy barrier of *CH4 on Ru1Mhost(111) (Mhost = Co, Ni, Cu and Au) falls within the range of 0.46–0.55 eV, a range that outperforms the activation energy observed on pure Pt(111) surfaces (0.58 eV). Notably, Rh1Ni(111), Ir1Ni(111), Ir1Cu(111), and Ir1Au(111) also exhibited activation energies almost identical to those observed on pure Pt(111) surfaces. These findings underscore the tremendous potential of SAAs in alkane dehydrogenation. 3.2 Feature engineering Any ML method tailored to predict a particular material property invariably hinges on a specific set of features. These features not only imbue a material with a unique identity but also forge crucial links between its physical and chemical attributes. In this study, we selected 23 initial features, including parameters such as atomic radii, lattice constants, surface energies of metallic elements, and dehydrogenation steps (the total features are listed in Tables S1 and S2). These features were chosen to describe the dehydrogenation energy barrier (E a) within the investigated chemical space. Although numerous factors can influence the desired material properties, it is imperative to limit the number of features. To gain an in-depth understanding of how features interact with target attributes while determining the optimal feature count, we assessed the initial features using the BAR algorithm (Fig. S2). With a feature count of 12, the model demonstrated the lowest RMSE (∼0.09 eV) value, signifying its optimal performance at this juncture. The optimal features encompass the lattice constants of the single-atom metal (a1) and host metal (a2), surface energies (α1 and α2), electronic affinities (β1 and β2), atomic radii (R1), and work functions (W1) of the single-atom metal, along with the atomic number (Z2), group number (G2), and atomic mass (γ2) of the host metal. Additionally, the number of dehydrogenation steps denoted as “s” is included as a crucial feature. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the number of dehydrogenation steps plays the most important role in the energy barrier of CH bond breaking, followed by the surface energy and lattice constants of the single-atom metal. Notably, the significance of the number of dehydrogenation steps outweighs that of the other features, signifying that the SAA surface is primarily influenced by the unsaturation of carbon atoms for CH bond activation. This provides a basis for achieving a balance between the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. To ensure the rationality of the feature set, we calculated Pearson correlation coefficient matrices to reveal correlations among pairs of features (Fig. 2 b). The minimal correlations observed among most features signify effective removal of redundant and irrelevant attributes. This refinement significantly improves the performance of the ML model. 3.3 Model training and test To determine the optimal training/testing set ratio, we analyzed the impact of the training set ratio on the accuracy of the model using the BAR algorithms (Figs. S3 and S4). The accuracy of the ML model improved as the proportion of the training set increased, reaching a peak at a training set proportion of 0.80. Consequently, the initial data derived from DFT calculations were randomly shuffled and divided into the training set and test set with an 8:2 ratio to ensure the generalization and accuracy of the models. Thus, the selection of an appropriate ML algorithm is crucial. In this study, we employed the aforementioned datasets and features to train eight different ML models, and the results are illustrated in Fig. 3 . The PolyLR, BRR, and (RFR algorithms display slightly subpar training results, with R 2 values falling below 0.80, implying the potential for larger prediction errors. In contrast, the ABR and KNR algorithms yielded moderate training outcomes. However, the (SISSO, GBR, and BAR algorithms all deliver commendable test results, boasting R 2 values surpassing 0.90 and RMSE values hovering around 0.10 eV within the test set. Among these, the BAR algorithm shows exceptional performance, achieving an impressive R 2 value of 0.98, and an exceptionally low RMSE of 0.06 eV. To assess the robustness of the model, we conducted 500 training sessions. The average RMSE and R 2 scores of the eight models after extensive training are illustrated in Figs. S5 and S6, respectively. The remarkable R 2 and RMSE values of the BAR model indicate its robustness and affirm its reliability. In addition, the linear relationship between the BAR-predicted results and DFT-calculated results within the dataset, along with the clustered distribution of R 2 scores in 500 trials, further illustrates that the effectively trained BAR model can attain a high level of prediction accuracy for the energy barrier of CH bond cleavage by learning from the original data. 3.4 Model prediction The top-performing BAR model, as determined during the training phase, was subsequently employed to predict the catalytic activities of the CH bond activation for 30 SAAs. The prediction results are shown in Fig. 4 . Indeed, it is evident that SAAs featuring the same single-atom but varying host metals display analogous color patterns in the heatmaps for each dehydrogenation reaction step. This observation indicates that these SAAs possess similar CH bond cleavage energy barriers on their surfaces, underscoring the likelihood that a single atom is the predominant factor influencing the dehydrogenation activity. Among them, Ru1Mhost exhibits a low dehydrogenation energy barrier in the first three steps of the dehydrogenation reaction. This underscores that Ru1Mhost is a promising candidate catalyst for alkane dehydrogenation reactions. Furthermore, the *CH dehydrogenation energy barrier is highlighted in red on the heatmap, signifying that the process necessitates overcoming an energy barrier surpassing 1.0 eV. This further underscores the distinct advantages of the Ru1Mhost SAA catalysts in preventing carbon deposition. 3.5 Analysis of ML features and physical insights To understand the structure–activity relationship of SAA catalysts, we embarked on a more profound exploration of their traits. Among the 12 characteristics, the dehydrogenation step “s” exerts the most significant influence on the activation energy. Consequently, to investigate the influence of the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst on the catalytic performance, each step of the dehydrogenation reaction must be individually scrutinized. As shown in Fig. 5 a–d, the paramount feature influencing the dehydrogenation of *CH4, *CH3, and *CH is the surface energy of the single-atom metal, with the atomic mass or lattice constant of the host metal following close importance. In the case of *CH2 dehydrogenation, the lattice constant of the single-atom metal takes precedence as the most critical feature, with the surface energy of the single-atom metal being of close importance. These findings suggest that single-atom metals play a pivotal role in influencing the dehydrogenation performance. Next, we delve into how predictions are influenced by altering the value of a single variable while keeping all other variables constant, providing further insights into the relationship between the variable and the response. Specifically, we investigated the correlation between the two most crucial features in each step of the dehydrogenation reaction and the energy barrier for dehydrogenation. During this process, all features, except the one under examination, were held constant at their respective average values in the dataset. In the *CH4 dehydrogenation process, a negative correlation exists between the CH bond breaking energy barrier and surface energy of the single-atom metal. The CH bond breaking energy barrier decreased as the surface energy of the single atom increased and stabilized when the surface energy reaches 2.3 J•m−2 (Fig. 5 e). To confirm the accuracy of this conclusion, we conducted statistical analysis of the actual values, as illustrated in Fig. 5 f. These results are consistent with our predictions and further support our findings. Likewise, our examination of the atomic mass of the host metal indicates that the variation in the CH bond cleavage energy barrier among different atomic masses is less than 0.10 eV (Fig. 5 g–5h). This finding suggests that this feature has minimal influence on the energy barrier for CH bond cleavage. Similarly, we conducted separate explorations of the impact of single-atom surface energy on CH bond cleavage during the dehydrogenation of *CH3, *CH2, and *CH. The variations in the CH bond breaking energy with different features are shown in Figs. 5 e and S7–S12. Remarkably, these results consistently demonstrate that the CH bond breaking energy barrier decreases with an increase in the surface energy (Figs. S7, S10, S11). These findings further suggest that Ru1Mhost has the potential to be a high-performance catalyst for alkane dehydrogenation. This result aligns with those of previous studies on the activity of pure metal-catalyzed alkane dehydrogenations. In the temperature range of 673–1173 K and at atmospheric pressure, the majority of studies indicated that the activity trend for the activation of CH followed the order Ru, Rh > Ni, Ir > Pt, Pd [2,47,48]. At 773 K, 1 bar, and 10 % conversion, the predicted methane steam reforming activity trend by Jones et al. using a theoretical model is Ru ∼ Rh > Ni ∼ Ir ∼ Pt ∼ Pd. In addition to theoretical calculations, the authors conducted experimental measurements of this activity. Assuming a negligible carrier effect, the obtained experimental activity trend at 773 K was Ru > Rh > Ir ∼ Ni ∼ Pt ∼ Pd [49]. While the modeling results may not align perfectly with the experimental findings, the overall consensus suggests that Ru exhibits the most potent activation capability for CH bonds among the metals considered. 3.6 Catalytic alkane dehydrogenation on Ru1Cu(111) SAA As shale gas exploration continues to expand globally, catalytic propane dehydrogenation from shale gas has become the third major method for propylene production [50,51]. To further validate the exceptional catalytic performance of the predicted candidates, we selected Ru1Cu(111) SAA, which is identified for its remarkably low dehydrogenation energy barrier predicted from our model and its relatively low cost for propane dehydrogenation. Since Pt catalysts are frequently used in propane dehydrogenation reactions due to their strong affinity for alkane CH bonds, in this study, we chose a Pt catalyst as a reference to evaluate the catalytic performance of the Ru1Cu(111) catalyst. This comparison allows us to assess the potential advantages of Ru1Cu(111) as a catalyst for propane dehydrogenation, which involves two dehydrogenation steps: the first step converts propane (*C3H8) into propyl species (*C3H7), and the second step converts propyl species (*C3H7) into propylene (*C3H6). Our DFT calculations (Fig. 6 a and Fig. S13) reveal that the Ru1Cu(111) surface provided lower thermodynamic barriers for the formation of propyl intermediate than the Pt(111) surface (0.36 eV on Ru1Cu(111) versus 0.55 eV on Pt(111)). The activation energies required for the dehydrogenation of propyl to propylene are similar on both Ru1Cu(111) and Pt(111) surfaces, with values of 0.64 eV and 0.68 eV, respectively. Therefore, propane activation on both Ru1Cu(111) and Pt(111) requires overcoming approximately the same energy barrier, indicating that the two catalysts exhibit similar activities. It is well known that a lower energy barrier for propylene over-dehydrogenation on Pt sites leads to inherent drawbacks, including a high propensity for coke deposition and reduced selectivity. Therefore, it is imperative to look into the propylene over-dehydrogenation and C–C bond cleavage processes. From Fig. 6 a, it is seen that the dehydrogenation energy barrier of propylene on Ru1Cu(111) is 1.00 eV, well surpassing 0.79 eV on Pt(111). Nevertheless, the exothermic desorption of propylene from both surfaces is approximately 1.60 eV. These results suggest that Ru1Cu(111) is more advantageous for inhibiting excessive dehydrogenation of propylene, thereby enhancing propylene selectivity. To assess the potential for carbon deposition, the C–C bond cleavage of the *C3H4 intermediate—widely regarded as a key precursor to coke formation—was first investigated [52,53]. The calculated free energy barrier for *C3H4 C–C bond scission on the Ru1Cu(111) surface is 1.65 eV (Fig. 6 a), which is over 0.50 eV higher than that on Pt(111), indicating that C–C bond cleavage is significantly suppressed on Ru1Cu(111), thereby effectively inhibiting carbon deposition. Additionally, we evaluated C–C bond cleavage for other intermediates including *C3H8, *C3H7, *C3H6, and *C3H5 (Fig. S17). The calculated barriers are 2.39 eV, 1.13 eV, 1.10 eV, and 1.11 eV, respectively—all of which are higher than the corresponding barriers for further dehydrogenation or desorption. These results collectively suggest that C–C bond cleavage is unfavorable on the Ru1Cu(111) surface, implying a strong resistance to coke formation during the dehydrogenation process. Additionally, we explored the dehydrogenation performance of ethane and isobutane on Ru1Cu(111), and the results are shown in Fig. 6 b and c and Figs. S14–S15. Ethane undergoes two consecutive steps of dehydrogenation in Ru1Cu(111), conquering energy barriers of 0.40 eV and 0.04 eV, successively, culminating in the production of ethylene. Conversely, on the Pt(111) surface, the energy barrier for the two-step dehydrogenation of ethane surpasses 0.50 eV. This highlights the superior performance of the Ru1Cu(111) catalyst in comparison to the Pt(111) catalyst for facilitating the dehydrogenation of ethane. Similarly, the energy barrier for the two-step dehydrogenation of isobutane to isobutylene on Ru1Cu(111) is notably lower (by more than 0.17 eV) compared than the corresponding dehydrogenation energy barrier on Pt(111). This provides further evidence of the exceptional performance of Ru1Cu(111) in catalyzing dehydrogenation reactions. Moreover, the energy required for ethylene generation and isobutylene desorption is significantly lower than the energy barrier for C–C bond activation, effectively preventing carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. As expected, these findings strongly suggest a promising application of Ru1Cu(111) SAA in alkane dehydrogenation reactions. Comparing the geometric and electronic structures of adsorbed alkanes on Ru1Cu(111) and Pt(111) surfaces provides valuable insights into the CH activation barriers (Fig. 6 d – 6i and Fig. S16). On the Ru1Cu(111) surface, ethane, propane, and isobutane adsorb 0.1 Å closer to the Ru atom compared to pure Pt(111), resulting in a shorter adsorption distance. This proximity enhances the charge density redistribution, transferring electronic density from the CH internuclear region to the H···Ru internuclear region. This electron redistribution is more pronounced on Ru1Cu(111) SAA than on Pt(111), indicating more effective activation of the alkanes. Therefore, a lower dehydrogenation energy barrier is observed on the Ru1Cu(111) surface. To gain deeper insights into the origin of the catalytic superiority of Ru1Cu(111), a comparative analysis of the electronic structures of Ru1Cu(111) and other M1Cu(111) SAAs (M = Ni, Rh, Pd, Ir, and Pt) was performed. As previously noted, the d-electronic structure plays a crucial role in determining the catalytic behavior of d-block SAAs [54]. Accordingly, the projected density of states (PDOS) for various SAAs was calculated (Fig. S18) to systematically examine the d-band characteristics of the dopant atoms. The results reveal that, in comparison with other M1Cu SAAs, the d-band center of the single atom in Ru1Cu(111) lies significantly closer to the Fermi level, indicating a stronger potential interaction with adsorbates. A clear correlation was observed between the d-band center of the dopant atom and the adsorption energy of propane on M1Cu SAAs. As the d-band center approaches the Fermi level, the adsorption strength increases, suggesting that Ru1Cu possesses an enhanced capability for propane activation (Fig. S19 and Table S3). To further evaluate the catalytic potential of Ru1Cu single-atom alloys for alkane dehydrogenation, detailed microkinetic simulations of propane dehydrogenation on Ru1Cu(111) and Pt(111) surfaces were performed. In the microkinetic model, we considered nine fundamental steps involved in the dehydrogenation of propane to propyne (as summarized in Table S4), including five elementary reaction steps corresponding to four consecutive dehydrogenation stages and hydrogen formation, as well as the adsorption and desorption processes of propane, propylene, propyne, and hydrogen. The microkinetic simulations in this study were conducted with an initial propane partial pressure of 101.325 kPa, a total feed flow rate of 1 × 10−3 mol/s, and a temperature range of 323–1023 K. A total simulation time of 100 s was employed to ensure that the system reached steady-state conditions. The simulation results are presented in Fig. 6 j–l. As the reaction temperature increases, the reaction rate rises markedly. Below 723 K, the propane consumption rate remains below 1 × 10−10 mol/s, indicating a sluggish dehydrogenation process. This observation aligns well with experimental findings, which report that effective propane dehydrogenation typically occurs at temperatures above 500 °C [55–57]. Notably, Ru1Cu(111) exhibits consistently higher catalytic activity than Pt(111) throughout the simulated temperature range, further supporting its excellent catalytic performance. Moreover, the production rate of propylene closely matches the consumption rate of propane and is more than four orders of magnitude higher than that of propyne, underscoring the excellent selectivity of the Ru1Cu(111) surface for propylene formation. The surface coverage of reaction intermediates at different temperatures was statistically analyzed (Fig. S20). On the Ru1Cu(111) surface, at temperatures below 373 K, the surface is predominantly covered by *C3H8 species, indicating that propane is difficult to activate under such low-temperature conditions. As the temperature increases, *C3H7 becomes the dominant surface species, which aligns with DFT results suggesting that the dehydrogenation of *C3H7 is the rate-determining step in the conversion of propane to propylene. Upon further increasing the temperature to 973 K, the coverage of *C3H6 exceeds 50 %, indicating the efficient formation and accumulation of propylene on the surface prior to desorption. In contrast, on the Pt(111) surface, *C3H8 remains the dominant surface species throughout the entire simulated temperature range, indicating that propane activation is kinetically hindered on Pt(111) under the given conditions. Comprehensive thermodynamic and dynamic stability analyses were performed, including formation energy, aggregation energy, and results from ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations. The calculated formation energy of Ru1Cu single-atom alloy (SAA) is –2.87 eV, in agreement with the value reported by Luo et al. [58], indicating its thermodynamically favorable formation. The aggregation energy, calculated as –0.48 eV, suggests a thermodynamic tendency for atom aggregation. However, the alloying process is complex and may be governed not only be by thermodynamics but also by kinetics [59] since Ru1Cu SAA has been successfully synthesized and detected. For example, Jung et al. synthesized atomic-scale Ru–Cu alloy nanoparticles using a carbon thermal shock (CTS) method involving rapid heating to 1100 °C. The formation of Ru1Cu SAA was confirmed via CO adsorption DRIFTS, aberration-corrected STEM-HAADF imaging, and EXAFS spectroscopy [60]. Furthermore, Duan, Tan, and Xu et al. prepared Ru1Cu SAAs through galvanic replacement and a combination of electrostatic adsorption with thermal reduction. The resulting catalysts exhibited excellent performance in the selective hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, C–N coupling reactions, and CO2 reduction reactions [61–63]. To assess high-temperature structural stability, AIMD simulations were carried out on Ru1Cu SAA at 773 K. As shown in Fig. S20a, the total energy remained stable around −243.5 eV throughout the simulation period, indicating that the single-atom structure is thermally robust. Under high Ru loading conditions, modeled by substituting two Cu atoms with Ru (Fig. S20b), no significant energy fluctuations were observed within 6000 fs, suggesting that the atomically dispersed structure remains stable even at elevated concentrations. In contrast, the dimerized Ru configuration on the Cu(111) surface (Fig. S20c) exhibited a noticeable increase in system energy after 3000 fs, indicating that despite its possible thermodynamic favorability, the dimer structure is dynamically unstable. Herein, we propose that although the aggregation of Ru1Cu SAA is thermodynamically favorable, this process may be kinetically hindered. This is supported by experimental observations, as the Ru1Cu SAA has been successfully synthesized and detected in the literature. Furthermore, our AIMD calculations indicate that the aggregation product is dynamically unstable, reinforcing the kinetic stabilization of the single-atom alloy. 4 Conclusion In summary, we investigated the catalytic activity of SAA catalysts for alkane dehydrogenation using a combined DFT and ML approach. The BAR algorithm, utilizing selected 12 features, emerged as the top-performing ML model, achieving an RMSE of 0.06 eV and an R 2 score of 0.98. Our feature analysis revealed that the attributes of single-atom metals exert a substantial influence on catalyst performance, while the host metal has a comparatively lesser impact on dehydrogenation performance. Remarkably, the surface energy of single-atom metals strongly influences the CH bond activation, with higher surface energy correlating to lower CH bond dissociation barrier. DFT calculations and microkinetic simulations further highlight the great potential of Ru1Cu(111) SAA for alkane dehydrogenation, revealing its superior activity compared to Pt catalysts in propane dehydrogenation, along with an enhanced resistance to over-dehydrogenation and carbon deposition. Moreover, Ru1Cu(111) SAA outperformed Pt catalysts in ethane and isobutane dehydrogenation. The study highlights the effectiveness of integrating DFT calculations and ML with feature engineering as a powerful tool for the rational design of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The recent surge in shale gas production has renewed interest in efficient alkane dehydrogenation for the synthesis of fuels and high-value chemicals. However, developing cost-effective catalysts that exhibit high catalytic activity while minimizing over-dehydrogenation and carbon deposition remains a significant challenge. Here, we integrate density functional theory (DFT) calculations with machine learning (ML) to design single-atom alloy (SAA) catalysts for efficient alkane dehydrogenation. Using DFT, we calculate 92 CH bond disassociation energy barriers to construct a dataset, which is used to train eight ML algorithms with 12 features. The top-performing Bagging Regression (BAR) model is then employed to predict CH bond activation energy barriers on the surfaces of 53 SAA candidates, enabling rapid screening of methane dehydrogenation activity. Among these, the Ru1Cu SAA catalyst exhibits outstanding activity, outperforming pure Pt. Detailed DFT calculations confirm that Ru1Cu(111) not only exhibits superior performance in methane dehydrogenation, but also exceptional activity in the dehydrogenation of propane, ethane, and isobutane. Moreover, microkinetic simulations further confirm the high selectivity of the Ru1Cu(111) surface toward propylene during propane dehydrogenation. Feature engineering analyses reveal the critical roles of dehydrogenation steps and the surface energy of the single-atom metal in influencing CH bond activation. These findings underscore the effectiveness of the DFT–ML framework for catalyst discovery and highlight Ru1Cu SAA as a highly active, selective, and stable catalyst with strong resistance to over-dehydrogenation and carbon deposition, making it a highly promising candidate for alkane dehydrogenation.
